comments.commentBody:
> "Hillary Clinton has described her senatorial style as a "work horse" rather than a "show horse." This article describes Sen. Warren's role the Senate as "more of an effective scold than a legislative heavyweight,"

REALITY-CHECK: In order to be effective, you have to be both show-horse, AND a 'smart work-horse
In Government, you have to move public opinion to get anything done, that upsets the applecarts of the 1%
* * *

IMHO, Ms Warren IS NOT an effective scold
. . . the one thing that she is MOST successful at is exciting hard-left liberals

In my view, she is far less effective than Barney Frank, Al Frankin, Barbara Boxer, Nancy Pelosi, Harry Reid, & etc

I listen to her whenever I run across her on the Tube somewhere, but IMHO, she is like a well-intentioned broken-clock {right twice a day}
** Her fixes for Entitlements only make them MORE insolvent, which isn't a problem for her, because she refuses to believe that they are insolvent not
** I support 'most' of her stuff on student debt, but it is a LIE that the Government is turning-a-profit off of student debt {fuzziest math possible}
The MOST important thing here is to drive the cost WAY down, to about what it used to be. Won't work for Harvard, but for State-Colleges & Communities, ABSOLUTELY. To do it we have to toss out EVERYTHING, but education
** WallStreet Insider Trading is not impossible to prosecute, 401Ks are a giant ripoff for people, Gusher for FinanceIndustry, StockMarket is now RIGGED flashTrades

Balance? What will Trump do to balance his ticket?
Warren brings balance. Warren is the inspiration that Clinton needs to win.

It is often said that a vice presidential candidate is chosen based on his or her ability to balance the ticket.  On the campaign trail, Hillary Clinton has described her senatorial style as a "work horse" rather than a "show horse."  This article describes Sen. Warren's role the Senate as "more of an effective scold than a legislative heavyweight,"  Is this the kind of balance Clinton needs?
Try rewriting your comment with no punctuation See how reads Good
If so, why do you use it.  Dispense with it for a while and see how that works out.

Arabic, Chinese/Japanese have done without it for centuries if not millennia. The syntax (SOV, VSO, etc.) and subordinate clause pre/post particles provide enough clues for ready comprehension

Well composed prose in any language, including English, does not need punctuation. In typewritten or typeset English text the end period matters little, as new paragraphs begin on a new line. But often in copy and paste between different formats the cr/lf character is obliterated, and paragraphs merge into a stream, the missing period can give a moment to pause

Well, language are never static; let us see how English evolves to accommodate missing period. Fortunately languages are not women, so a missing period should not be a cause for panic, lol
? Perhaps...

The dropping of the period, or any other punctuation, has more to do with minimizing the buttons you have to push to compose a text message, I think. You can find many more examples of how written communication has changed due to text messaging. Part of this is probably due to a desire to conserve energy. The character limits imposed by Twitter also contributes a bit. Words are regularly shortened, truncated and abbreviated. And, IMO, the younger you are, the more shortcuts you know and use regularly.

I googled Meldonium when this first arose in the news, and Mildronate is immediately issued. Ms. Sharapova did not disclose all her meds on the required forms.  In the military, we do this routinely for unannounced urinalysis.  No mitigating factors in my book.

Even better than "latr" is "l8r"!

As for "lite," that "trend" has actually entered the English lexicon according to Merriam Webster. Look it up at m-w.com.
Back in the 40s or 50s, the Chicago Tribune tried to promote abbreviating spelling of many words.  It didn't catch on then but I still use thru for through, lite, tho for though, etc.

Nonsense. Until this "trend" enters the world of office email, which it assuredly has not, then it's a trend the same as "lite" and "c u latr". These are gimmicky shorthands, and not using a period properly is the same laziness as not capitalizing the first letter of a sentence or the letter "i" when one means "I"; nothing but affectations. So lite'n up.

Once more: A carriage return is a mechanical operation or digital signal. It can appear in different ways depending on your computer system. Please say "start a new line" or "skip a line" if that is what you mean. (I hope it is not; I hope you mean "start a new paragraph".))

I'm picking only on people who are picking on this article but being imprecise themselves.
Might have made the interpretation of the second ammendment less controversial.
Great idea. Replace every period with a carriage return and a line space.  Try that on the Declaration of Independence.

To me, this whole study seems completely pointless.

I guess the period had its time
Wooden rackets. Aluminum, carbon fiber, whatever they are using should be banned.
So easy, with EMPEROR PALPATINE setting up the rest of the board (had one crossword before seeing the giveaway.) But I STILL HAVE ONE LETTER WRONG SOMEWHERE, and I don't want to lose my streak at 9.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
Take any athlete you like and add 5 years to their age. How dare you condemn Maria to never playing at the top of her ability again - for taking something that HAS BEEN legal - AND prescribed.

This isn't like Barry Bonds.
Her team wouldn't have been able to advise her against taking the drug because she never told them she was taking it. The only ones who knew she was taking it were herself, her father and her agent.

Players were advised a year prior of the drugs that would be added to the list, so there was a grace period. As to Sharapova's health reasons, the drug was prescribed in 2006, but no subsequent visits to a doctor justified its continued use.

I've read the PDF on the decision regarding Maria's case. I think the decision was fair. Lenient even. She withheld that she was taking this drug from her team, her coach, her physic, her trainer, her nutritionist, pretty much everyone. She never declared it on any forms as something she was taking prior to drug tests. She was hiding this. Maria is often known for her mental toughness. Did she have this strength because of discipline or because she knew she could outlast anyone because of the drug? It brings into question her big wins and the major titles she has won.

At this point. Maria is doing damage control. She's not going to win this fight. She is suspended, but what she is trying to do is keep her fans. Her post on Facebook only tells a small part of the whole story. The hardcore Maria fans will read her post and believe anything she says and disregard anything else.
Bob Dylan and countless others.

Hatred of Ali throughout the US was profound in the 60s and 70s, effecting treatment by even the supposedly objective and fair minded news media. Imagine the public outcry if the NYT, Wash Post and other newspapers had chosen to routinely publish/use the given names of movie stars rather than their chosen Hollywood names.

Fred Astaire - Frederick Austerlitz

Lauren Bacall - Betty Joan Perske

Brigitte Bardot - Camille Javal

Red Buttons - Aaron Chwatt

Tony Curtis - Bernard Schwartz

Joan Crawford - Lucille Le Sueur

Kirk Douglas - Issur Danielovitch

Dale Evans - Frances Octavia Smith

Cary Grant - Archibald Leach

Charlton Heston - Charles Carter

Rock Hudson - Roy Scherer Jr.

Danny Kaye - David Kaminsky

Boris Karloff - William Henry Pratt

Marilyn Monroe - Norma Jean Baker

Slim Pickens - Louis Lindley

John Wayne - Marion Michael Morrison
"What's my name?"  meant so much more.

When did the Gray Lady call Lew Alcindor by his chosen name, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar?
Not to make anything of it, but it's curious that no mention is made of such a prominent example.

I remember the pettiness of so many, including the Times, as this article makes clear. But to characterize this as a style issue, or a typographical convenience, strains the imagination. Even in death, some of the commenters on Ali’s obituary insisted on referring to him as Cassius Clay, as if insulting his memory would somehow give them an increased sense of worth.

We’ve made some progress since 1965, when a man couldn’t even choose his own name. Yes, today, Chelsea Manning is automatically referred to as ‘her’ or ‘she’. But Chelsea Manning, for an act of conscience not so different from Ali’s, is still in jail. Maybe Bradley Manning should have learned to box.

Racism was really pervasive and overt back then.
You'd be amazed by the articles from the NYT archives (one of the perks of online subscription).
MLK and Ali were by far the most hated black men in America during those years. It's funny how their reputations improved only after their voices were silenced by murder and disease... They were less threatening that way.
MLK went from a "troublemaker and race-hustler" to a whitewashed, saintly figure who gave that kumbaya speech in 1963. The same thing happened to Ali after Parkison's robbed him of his voice.
I think it was more or less because Mr. Ali refused to go to war!

You're giving the Times a free pass on its arrogance by saying that other people did it, too. Howard Cosell began calling Ali by his new name almost immediately; what's your excuse?

My sneaking suspicion is that the Times didn't want an uppity black man telling them what to call him if that name didn't fit with the paper's preconceived notion of what he should be called.

Yeah, either that, or one was white, with a bland name, while the other was black, with a religious, provocative, politically charged name and politically motivated one. But I'm sure you considered that angle, too.

Comparing Ali's name change to John Wayne's is like compares apples and oranges. Ali changed his name after he won his first heavyweight title, so he had already gained international fame by then. The Times was right to insist that he change his name in a court of law for the new name to be recognized.

No one knew who John Wayne was when he adopted his screen name, so no one cared.

In the case of "Saddam", you might also remember president Bush the First insistence on pronouncing the name in a way that by itself would give him a license to kill with a large sector of America's pious population. Bush pronounced the name in a way that made it sound like "Sodom", hence making the punishment for Iraq inevitable. G.H.W. Bush is God's main man on the block at the time. Hence "Saddam" and "Sodom".

In the case of "Saddam", you might also remember president Bush the First insistence on pronouncing the name in a way that by itself would give him a license to kill with a large sector of America's pious population. Bush pronounced the name in a way that made it sound like "Sodom", hence making the punishment for Iraq inevitable. G.H.W. Bush is God's main man on the block at the time. Hence "Saddam" and "Sodom".

If it is "'much more the norm now not to impose a name on someone'" at the NYT, in addition to "about time," one might add: "apply the same rule to countries and rulers of countries."

What do I mean?

"Myanmar," which the NYT, at least until very recently, has insisted on calling "Burma." Does the NYT believe countries can't name themselves anything the NYT doesn't prefer?

"Saddam Hussein," who news reporters, headline writers, and especially NYT columnists, referred to as "Saddam." What other foreign leader got or gets this treatment? It was clearly going along with those who sought to denigrate and diminish Mr. Hussein and, in doing so, help make the case for war with Iraq a "slam dunk." (Wait, I do remember hearing of someone else who got this treatment. Adolf. Which I would assert, merely reinforces my preceding charge.)

Countries and people deserve to be called by the names they call themselves. And they deserver the same respect the NYT gives to musicians like Prince. Admiration or disgust with individuals and countries does not somehow give the NYT the right to assign them names they don't call themselves.
A gladiator with a golden heart.
Under the conditions and circumstance of his injury, that is about the best thing for Rafael Nadal to do.

Nobody gives it his all on the tennis court more than Nadal. It has been a great pleasure to watch him all these years. We hope he has some left in him. My wife says he is a great manly specimen and she loves to admire him. He generous to his opponent in victory and he doesn't come up with excuses in defeat. He seems like someone who would be a good role mode.

Phil. Miazga started TWO matches for Chel$ki, of the 16 league matches Chel$ki played after he transferred in, with a total of 135 minutes played. You want him instead of Brooks, who had a breakout season at Europa League qualified Hertha or Geoff Cameron, who was a regular at top half Stoke? Um, no.
